verses.text: Then the LORD said to me, 'Even if Moses and Samuel stood before Me, My heart would not be toward this people. Send them away from My presence, and let them go.'
verses.comment: God tells Jeremiah that even the intercession of the greatest mediators, Moses and Samuel, would not save the rebellious people this time. This emphasizes the severity of their sin and foreshadows the need for a mediator greater than Moses or Samuel, ultimately fulfilled in Christ (cf. Heb. 3:1-6; 1 Tim. 2:5).

verses.text: If they ask you, ‘Where shall we go?’ say to them, ‘This is what the LORD says: Those destined for death, to death; those for the sword, to the sword; those for famine, to famine; those for captivity, to captivity.’
verses.comment: The fourfold judgment highlights the comprehensive nature of God's justice. The phrase repeats in Revelation 13:10, symbolizing the inevitability of divine judgment. The notion of God's justice is a call to repentance—a theme culminating in the New Covenant's hope through Christ (cf. Luke 21:24).

verses.text: I will appoint four kinds of judgment against them, declares the LORD: the sword to kill, the dogs to drag off, the birds of the heavens and the beasts of the earth to devour and destroy.
verses.comment: This judgment is reminiscent of covenant curses (Deut. 28:26). The use of animals as instruments of judgment points to the seriousness of breaking covenant and foreshadows New Testament teachings on the necessity of remaining in God's grace (cf. John 15:6).

verses.text: I will make them a horror to all the kingdoms of the earth because of Manasseh son of Hezekiah, king of Judah, for all the evil he did in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: The sins of King Manasseh brought national disaster (cf. 2 Kings 21:11). This also shows the consequences of leadership that turns away from God, a reminder of the importance of faithful succession in leadership roles within the people of God.

verses.text: For who will have pity on you, Jerusalem, or who will mourn for you? Who will turn aside to ask about your welfare?
verses.comment: Jerusalem’s spiritual isolation is highlighted—no one will intercede or offer comfort. This sets the stage for the future coming of Christ, the true Comforter (cf. John 14:16), and the communion of saints who bear one another's burdens.

verses.text: You have rejected Me, declares the LORD; you keep turning back. So I will stretch out My hand against you and destroy you; I am weary of relenting.
verses.comment: God’s patience is not limitless. Persistent unfaithfulness leads to judgment, underscoring the importance of ongoing repentance and remaining in God’s favor.

verses.text: I have winnowed them with a pitchfork at the gates of the land; I have bereaved them, I have destroyed My people; yet they did not turn from their ways.
verses.comment: God is depicted as the righteous Judge separating the faithful from the unfaithful, a theme picked up by John the Baptist and Jesus regarding the final judgment (cf. Matthew 3:12; Luke 3:17).

verses.text: Their widows are more numerous before Me than the sand of the seas. I have brought upon them a destroyer at noon; I have hurled upon the mother and the young man sudden anguish and terror.
verses.comment: The devastation is total; suffering falls on mothers and sons. This highlights the seriousness of sin and God’s call for the community in faith to support those suffering loss.

verses.text: She who bore seven languishes; she breathes her last. Her sun sets while it is still day; she is put to shame and humiliated. I will give the rest of them to the sword before their enemies, says the LORD.
verses.comment: This poetic language signifies the complete loss of hope. The number seven symbolizes completeness, so the loss is total. It prefigures the need for spiritual renewal through the Messiah.

verses.text: Woe to me, my mother, that you gave birth to me, a man of strife and contention to all the land! I have not lent or borrowed, yet everyone curses me.
verses.comment: Jeremiah expresses despair, facing opposition despite innocent conduct. This reflects the suffering of the righteous, pointing to Christ who suffered for righteousness' sake (cf. Matt. 5:11; 1 Pet. 2:23).

verses.text: The LORD said, 'Surely I will set you free for a good purpose; surely I will make the enemy plead with you in times of disaster and distress.'
verses.comment: God promises protection for Jeremiah, foreshadowing the preservation of God’s chosen leaders. Like other biblical figures, Jeremiah will be delivered for God’s purposes. This prefigures Christ as the perfect Prophet who is preserved by God (cf. John 19:36).

verses.text: Can anyone break iron—iron from the north—or bronze?
verses.comment: The iron from the north likely refers to Babylon's irresistible power. God’s judgment is depicted as unbreakable. It is only God who can redeem, a theme that runs into New Testament teachings on grace and redemption.

verses.text: Your wealth and your treasures I will give as plunder, without price, because of all your sins throughout your territory.
verses.comment: Loss of material blessing is a result of persistent sin. This reflects Jesus’ teachings about laying up treasures in heaven and not earthly wealth (cf. Matthew 6:19-21).

verses.text: I will make you serve your enemies in a land you do not know, for My anger is kindled with fire that will burn against you.
verses.comment: Exile is a just consequence for covenant breaking. Exile imagery later becomes a theme of spiritual exile, fulfilled in Christ's return and gathering of God's people.

verses.text: LORD, You know; remember me and take notice of me, and avenge me on my persecutors. In Your patience, do not take me away; know that for Your sake I have suffered reproach.
verses.comment: Jeremiah appeals to God for justice—he suffers for faithfulness. This anticipates Christ’s suffering and His call to rejoice when sharing in His reproach (cf. Hebrews 13:13; 1 Peter 4:14).

verses.text: Your words were found, and I ate them; and Your words became to me a joy and the delight of my heart, for I am called by Your name, O LORD, God of hosts.
verses.comment: Jeremiah 'eating' God’s words foreshadows the call to receive God’s Word both spiritually and truly. This hints at the spiritual food of the New Covenant (cf. John 6:51,63).

verses.text: I did not sit in the company of those who make merry, nor did I rejoice. I sat alone, because Your hand was upon me, for You had filled me with indignation.
verses.comment: Jeremiah’s prophetic vocation required a holy separation from sinners—a prelude to Christ’s call for spiritual purity and self-denial (cf. Luke 9:23).

verses.text: Why is my pain unending and my wound incurable, refusing to be healed? Will You truly be to me like a deceitful stream, like waters that fail?
verses.comment: Jeremiah questions God’s faithfulness amid suffering, yet within this is a call to trust. This resonates with Jesus’ cry on the cross (Matthew 27:46), showing the depth of engagement in prayer even during distress.

verses.text: Therefore thus says the LORD: 'If you return, I will restore you, and you shall stand before Me. If you extract the precious from the worthless, you will be as My mouth. They shall turn to you, but you must not turn to them.'
verses.comment: God invites Jeremiah (and by extension, all leaders) to repentance and steadfastness, promising restoration and authority. Standing ‘before Me’ hints at ongoing intercession in God’s presence—a prefiguration of Christ’s mediation and the ministry of the apostles.

verses.text: I will make you to this people a fortified wall of bronze; they will fight against you, but they will not prevail over you, for I am with you to save you and deliver you, says the LORD.
verses.comment: Jeremiah is assured of strength from God to stand against opposition, foreshadowing the divine foundation and protection promised to God's faithful people (cf. Matt. 16:18—'the gates of hell shall not prevail'). This also subtly points to the perpetual protection of God’s true assembly.

verses.text: 'I will deliver you from the hand of the wicked and redeem you from the grasp of the ruthless.'
verses.comment: God’s final promise is deliverance and redemption, themes fulfilled in Christ and extended through His followers. The rescue from wickedness prefigures final salvation and the role of the faithful as God’s redeemed people.
